name: How To Clean Clams - The Best Way to Purge Sand
description: Learn how to purge the sand and grit from fresh clams with my step-by-step guide and video. This method is the best and easiest way to clean clams for a recipe!

itemListElement.text: Live clams should be cooked within 48 hours of purchase. Even though you do not use the clams right away, it‘s important to de-grit them first as soon as you bring the clams home from the store. Keeping the clams in the refrigerator will slow them down and they may not purge sand later.

itemListElement.text: Gather all the ingredients. Gently tap any clams with open shells and discard any clams that do not close their shells within a few minutes or that have cracked or chipped shells.
itemListElement.name: Gather all the ingredients. Gently tap any clams with open shells and discard any clams that do not close their shells within a few minutes or that have cracked or chipped shells.

itemListElement.text: To make the salt water, combine 2 cups water and 1 Tbsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt in a measuring cup or bowl and mix well until the salt is completely dissolved. For my setup, I doubled the ingredients to 4 cups water and 2 Tbsp kosher salt.
itemListElement.name: To make the salt water, combine 2 cups water and 1 Tbsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt in a measuring cup or bowl and mix well until the salt is completely dissolved. For my setup, I doubled the ingredients to 4 cups water and 2 Tbsp kosher salt.

itemListElement.text: Place a wire rack/sieve inside the large tray/bowl and put the clams in a single layer. The purged sand goes to the bottom of the rack/sieve and it will not be consumed again by the clams. Pour the salt water into the tray/bowl. The salt water should be right around the clam’s mouth. Don‘t submerge the clams under the salt water! If there isn’t enough salt water, then make more using the same ratio of water and salt.

The purged sand goes to the bottom of the rack/sieve and it will not be consumed again by the clams. Pour the salt water into the tray/bowl. The salt water should be right around the clam’s mouth. itemListElement.text: Cover the top with aluminum foil (clams prefer to be in a quiet and dark environment), leaving some space at the corner for air. Keep it in a cool dark place for 1 hour. Clams become active when water is around 69ºF/20ºC. If you live in a hot climate, you may need to adjust the water temperature between the refrigerator and a cool place in your house. If you get your own clams from the beach, you will need about 6 hours for clams to purge sand.

itemListElement.text: After 1 hour, remove the aluminum foil cover and take out the rack/sieve. Discard the dirty salt water and clean the tray/bowl.
itemListElement.name: After 1 hour, remove the aluminum foil cover and take out the rack/sieve. Discard the dirty salt water and clean the tray/bowl.

recipeInstructions.name: To Purge the Salt from Clams

itemListElement.text: This step is only for clams that you got from clamming yourself. Place the rack/sieve again to de-salt as the clams contain a lot of seawater. Keep the clams in the sieve and leave them at the counter for 1 hour. Without this process, the clams may taste too salty.
itemListElement.name: This step is only for clams that you got from clamming yourself. Place the rack/sieve again to de-salt as the clams contain a lot of seawater. Keep the clams in the sieve and leave them at the counter for 1 hour. Without this process, the clams may taste too salty.

itemListElement.text: Wash each clam with a brush under cold running water.
itemListElement.name: Wash each clam with a brush under cold running water.

itemListElement.text: Now the clams are ready! Put the clean clams in a bowl/tray and cover them with a damp paper towel on top. Keep it in the refrigerator for up to 2 days. To freeze, place the live clean clams in a plastic bag and remove the air. Store it in the freezer for 2 weeks.

review.reviewBody:
Hi Nami! Thanks for your recipe.
Where did you get the wire sieve with basin that you used on this post?  (how to clean clams)  It looks very nice and functional.
Also, do you have a recommendation for a good salt grinder?  I have used XO brand, but the base, where it twists, wears out over time.
Thanks!
